Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly an olpe; interior reserved; exterior: black-figure lion to right (neck and shoulder remaining with added red on mane and belly).
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Gorgon Painter
Curator's comments: The curve of the lion's neck suggests it may have been looking back with part of its ruff preserved at the top of the sherd; compare 1888,0601.588h. Compare Athens, Agora P 10650 in ABV, 11, no. 11 and Agora XXIII, pl. 68, no. 704. According to Venit: "These early fragments from Naukratis should date close to the turn of the century, making Naukratis among the earliest, if not the earliest, overseas market for vases from his [the Gorgon Painter's] workshop." (Venit 1984, 164)
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B103.20.4)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p.144, note 24 and p. 146, fig. 9)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 300, no. B292)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0284) (Phase 1)
